column1: Key West (Spanish: Cayo Hueso) is an island in the Straits of Florida
column2: within the U.S. state of Florida. Together with all or parts of the separate islands of Dredgers Key
column3: Fleming Key
column4: Sunset Key
column5: and the northern part of Stock Island
column6: it constitutes the City of Key West.

column1: The Island of Key West is about 4 miles (6 kilometers) long and 1 mile (2 km) wide
column2: with a total land area of 4.2 square miles (11 km2). It lies at the southernmost end of U.S. Route 1
column3: the longest north–south road in the United States. Key West is about 95 miles (153 km) north of Cuba at their closest points. It is also 130 miles (210 km) southwest of Miami by air
column4: about 165 miles (266 km) by road
column5: and 106 miles (171 km) north-northeast of Havana.The City of Key West is the county seat of Monroe County
column6: which includes all of the Florida Keys and part of the Everglades. The total land area of the city is 5.6 square miles (14.5 km2). The official city motto is "One Human Family".

column1: Key West is the southernmost city in the contiguous United States and the westernmost island connected by highway in the Florida Keys. Duval Street
column2: its main street
column3: is 1.1 miles (1.8 km) in length in its 14-block-long crossing from the Gulf of Mexico to the Straits of Florida and the Atlantic Ocean. Key West is the southern terminus of U.S. Route 1
column4: State Road A1A
column5: the East Coast Greenway and
column6: before 1935
column7: the Florida East Coast Railway. Key West is a port of call for many passenger cruise ships. The Key West International Airport provides airline service. Naval Air Station Key West is an important year-round training site for naval aviation due to the tropical weather
column8: which is also the reason Key West was chosen as the site of President Harry S. Truman's Winter White House. The central business district is located along Duval Street and includes much of the northwestern corner of the island.

column1: At various times before the 19th century
column2: people who were related or subject to the Calusa and the Tequesta inhabited Key West. The last Native American residents of Key West were Calusa refugees who were taken to Cuba when Florida was transferred from Spain to Great Britain in 1763.Cayo Hueso (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈkaʝo ˈweso]) is the original Spanish name for the island of Key West. Spanish-speaking people today also use the term when referring to Key West. It literally means "bone cay"
column3: cay referring to a low island or reef. It is said that the island was littered with the remains (bones) of prior native inhabitants
column4: who used the isle as a communal graveyard. This island was the westernmost Key with a reliable supply of water.Between 1763
column5: when Great Britain took control of Florida from Spain
column6: and 1821
column7: when the United States took possession of Florida from Spain
column8: there were few or no permanent inhabitants anywhere in the Florida Keys. Cubans and Bahamians regularly visited the Keys
column13: and salvaged wrecks. Smugglers and privateers also used the Keys for concealment. In 1766 the British governor of East Florida recommended that a post be set up on Key West to improve control of the area
column14: but nothing came of it. During both the British and Spanish periods no nation exercised de facto control. The Bahamians apparently set up camps in the Keys that were occupied for months at a time
column15: and there were rumors of permanent settlements in the Keys by 1806 or 1807
column16: but the locations are not known. Fishermen from New England started visiting the Keys after the end of the War of 1812
column17: and may have briefly settled on Key Vaca in 1818.

column2: the Spanish governor of Cuba in Havana deeded the island of Key West to Juan Pablo Salas
column3: an officer of the Royal Spanish Navy Artillery posted in Saint Augustine
column4: Florida.  After Florida was transferred to the United States in 1821
column5: Salas was so eager to sell the island that he sold it twice – first for a sloop valued at $575 to a General John Geddes
column6: a former governor of South Carolina
column7: and then to a U.S. businessman John W. Simonton
column8: during a meeting in a Havana café on January 19
column11: 000 in pesos in 1821.  Geddes tried in vain to secure his rights to the property before Simonton who
column12: with the aid of some influential friends in Washington
column13: was able to gain clear title to the island.  Simonton had wide-ranging business interests in Mobile
column14: Alabama.  He bought the island because a friend
column16: had drawn his attention to the opportunities presented by the island's strategic location.  John Whitehead had been stranded in Key West after a shipwreck in 1819 and he had been impressed by the potential offered by the deep harbor of the island.  The island was indeed considered the "Gibraltar of the West" because of its strategic location on the 90-mile (140 km)–wide deep shipping lane
column18: between the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico.

column3: Lt. Commander Matthew C. Perry sailed the schooner USS Shark to Key West and planted the U.S. flag
column4: claiming the Keys as United States property. No protests were made over the American claim on Key West
column5: so the Florida Keys became the property of the United States.

column1: After claiming the Florida Keys for the United States
column2: Perry renamed Cayo Hueso (Key West) to Thompson's Island for Secretary of the Navy Smith Thompson
column3: and the harbor Port Rodgers in honor of War of 1812 hero and President of the Navy Supervisors Board John Rodgers.  In 1823
column4: Commodore David Porter of the United States Navy West Indies Anti-Pirate Squadron took charge of Key West
column5: which he ruled (but
column6: according to some
column7: exceeding his authority) as military dictator under martial law. The United States Navy gave Porter the mission of countering piracy and the slave trade in the Key West area.

column2: John Simonton subdivided the island into plots and sold three undivided quarters of each plot to:

column1: John Mountain and U.S. Consul John Warner
column2: who quickly resold their quarter to Pardon C. Greene
column3: who took up residence on the island. Greene is the only one of the four "founding fathers" to establish himself permanently on the island
column4: where he became quite prominent as head of P.C. Greene and Company. He was a member of the city council and also served briefly as mayor. He died in 1838 at the age of 57.

column2: his friend who had advised him to buy Key West. John Whitehead lived in Key West for only eight years. He became a partner in the firm of P.C. Greene and Company from 1824 to 1827. A lifelong bachelor
column3: he left the island for good in 1832. He came back only once
column4: during the Civil War in 1861
column5: and died the next year.

column1: John Fleeming (nowadays spelled Fleming). John W.C. Fleeming was English-born and was active in mercantile business in Mobile
column2: Alabama
column3: where he befriended John Simonton. Fleeming spent only a few months in Key West in 1822 and left for Massachusetts
column4: where he married. He returned to Key West in 1832 with the intention of developing salt manufacturing on the island but died the same year at the age of 51.Simonton spent the winter in Key West and the summer in Washington
column5: where he lobbied hard for the development of the island and to establish a naval base on the island
column6: both to take advantage of the island's strategic location and to bring law and order to the town. He died in 1854.

column1: The names of the four "founding fathers" of modern Key West were given to main arteries of the island when it was first platted in 1829 by William Adee Whitehead
column2: John Whitehead's younger brother. That first plat and the names used remained mostly intact and are still in use today. Duval Street
column3: the island's main street
column4: is named after Florida's first territorial governor
column5: who served between 1822 and 1834 as the longest-serving governor in Florida's U.S. history.

column1: William Whitehead became chief editorial writer for the "Enquirer"
column2: a local newspaper
column3: in 1834. He preserved copies of his newspaper as well as copies from the "Key West Gazette"
column4: its predecessor. He later sent those copies to the Monroe County clerk for preservation
column5: which gives us a view of life in Key West in the early days (1820–1840).

column2: Key West was the richest city per capita in the United States.In 1852 the first Catholic Church
column3: St. Mary's Star-Of-The-Sea was built. The year 1864 became a landmark for the church in South Florida when five Sisters of the Holy Names of Jesus and Mary arrived from Montreal
column4: Canada
column5: and established the first Catholic school in South Florida. At the time it was called Convent of Mary Immaculate. The school is still operating today and is now known as Mary Immaculate Star of the Sea School.

column1: === American Civil War and late 19th century ===

column2: while Florida seceded and joined the Confederate States of America
column3: Key West remained in U.S. Union hands because of the naval base.  Most locals were sympathetic to the Confederacy
column4: however
column5: and many flew Confederate flags over their homes.  Fort Zachary Taylor
column6: constructed from 1845 to 1866
column7: was an important Key West outpost during the Civil War. Construction began in 1861 on two other forts
column8: East and West Martello Towers
column9: which served as side armories and batteries for the larger fort. When completed
column10: they were connected to Fort Taylor by railroad tracks for movement of munitions.  Fort Jefferson
column11: located about 68 miles (109 km) from Key West on Garden Key in the Dry Tortugas
column12: served after the Civil War as the prison for Dr. Samuel A. Mudd
column13: convicted of conspiracy for setting the broken leg of John Wilkes Booth
column14: the assassin of President Abraham Lincoln.

column2: major industries included wrecking
column3: fishing
column4: turtling
column5: and salt manufacturing. From 1830 to 1861
column6: Key West was a major center of U.S. salt production
column7: harvesting the commodity from the sea (via receding tidal pools) rather than from salt mines. After the outbreak of the Civil War
column8: Union troops shut down the salt industry after Confederate sympathizers smuggled the product into the South. Salt production resumed at the end of the war
column9: but the industry was destroyed by an 1876 hurricane and never recovered
column10: in part because of new salt mines on the mainland.During the Ten Years' War (an unsuccessful Cuban war for independence in the 1860s and 1870s)
column11: many Cubans sought refuge in Key West.

column2: 1886 that started at a coffee shop next to the San Carlos Institute and spread out of control
column3: destroyed 18 cigar factories and 614 houses and government warehouses.By 1889
column4: Key West was the largest and wealthiest city in Florida.The USS Maine sailed from Key West on her fateful visit to Havana
column5: where she blew up and sank in Havana Harbor
column6: igniting the Spanish–American War. Crewmen from the ship are buried in Key West
column7: and the Navy investigation into the blast occurred at the Key West Customs House.

column1: Key West was relatively isolated until 1912
column2: when it was connected to the Florida mainland via the Overseas Railway extension of Henry M. Flagler's Florida East Coast Railway (FEC).  Flagler created a landfill at Trumbo Point for his railyards.  The Labor Day Hurricane of 1935 destroyed much of the railroad and killed hundreds of residents
column3: including around 400 World War I veterans who were living in camps and working on federal road and mosquito-control projects in the Middle Keys. The FEC could not afford to restore the railroad.

column1: The U.S. government then rebuilt the rail route as an automobile highway
column2: completed in 1938
column3: built atop many of the footings of the railroad.  It became an extension of U.S. Route 1.  The portion of U.S. 1 through the Keys is called the Overseas Highway.  Franklin Roosevelt toured the road in 1939.

column1: Pan American Airlines was founded in Key West
column2: originally to fly visitors to Havana
column3: in 1926. The airline contracted with the United States Postal Service in 1927 to deliver mail to and from Cuba and the United States. The mail route was known as the Key West
column4: Florida – Havana Mail Route.

column1: John F. Kennedy was to use "90 miles from Cuba" extensively in his speeches against Fidel Castro. Kennedy himself visited Key West a month after the resolution of the Cuban Missile Crisis.
Prior to the Cuban revolution of 1959
column2: there were regular ferry and airplane services between Key West and Havana.
the city of Key West briefly asserted independence as the Conch Republic as a protest over a United States Border Patrol blockade. This blockade was set up on US 1
column3: where the northern end of the Overseas Highway meets the mainland at Florida City
column4: in response to the Mariel Boatlift. A traffic jam of 17 miles (27 km) ensued while the Border Patrol stopped every car leaving the Keys
column5: supposedly searching for illegal immigrants attempting to enter the mainland United States. This paralyzed the Florida Keys
column6: which rely heavily on the tourism industry. Flags
column7: T-shirts and other merchandise representing the Conch Republic are still popular souvenirs for visitors to Key West
column8: and the Conch Republic Independence Celebration– including parades and parties –is celebrated annually

column1: Key West is an island located at 24°33′55″N 81°46′33″W in the Straits of Florida. The island is about 4 miles (6 km) long and 1 mile (2 km) wide
column2: with a total land area of 4.2 square miles (10.9 km2; 2
column3: 688.0 acres). The average elevation above sea level is about 8 feet (2.4 m) and the maximum elevation is about 18 feet (5.5 m)
column4: within a 1-acre (0-hectare) area known as Solares Hill.The city of Key West is the southernmost city in the contiguous United States
column5: and the island is the westernmost island connected by highway in the Florida Keys. The city boundaries include the island of Key West and several nearby islands
column6: as well as the section of Stock Island north of U.S. Route 1
column7: on the adjacent key to the east. The total land area of the city is 5.6 square miles (15 km2). Sigsbee Park—originally known as Dredgers Key—and Fleming Key
column8: both located to the north
column9: and Sunset Key located to the west are all included in the city boundaries. Both Fleming Key and Sigsbee Park are part of Naval Air Station Key West and are inaccessible to the general public.

column1: Key West and most of the rest of the Florida Keys are on the dividing line between the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico. The two bodies have different currents
column2: with the calmer and warmer Gulf of Mexico being characterized by great clumps of seagrass. The area where the two bodies merge between Key West and Cuba is called the Straits of Florida. The warmest ocean waters anywhere on the United States mainland are found in the Florida Keys in winter
column3: with sea surface temperatures averaging in the 75–77 °F (24–25 °C) range in December through February.

column1: Key West is closer to Havana (about 106 miles or 171 kilometres by air or sea) than it is to Miami (130 miles or 210 kilometres by air or 165 miles or 266 kilometres by road). Key West is the usual endpoint for marathon swims from Cuba

The basic features that distinguish the local architecture include wood-frame construction of one- to two-and-a-half-story structures set on foundation piers about three feet (one meter) above the ground. Exterior characteristics of the buildings are peaked metal roofs

column6: side-hinged louvered shutters

column1: ==== Southernmost point in the United States ====

One of the most popular attractions on the island is a concrete replica of a buoy at the corner of South and Whitehead Streets that claims to be the southernmost point in the contiguous United States. The point was originally marked with a basic sign. The city of Key West erected the current monument in 1983. The monument was repainted after damage by Hurricane Irma in 2017
column2: and is the most often photographed tourist site in the Florida Keys.

column1: The monument is labeled "Southernmost point continental U.S.A."
column2: though Whitehead Spit is the actual southernmost point of Key West
column3: on the Truman Annex property just west of the buoy. The spit has no marker since it is on U.S. Navy land that cannot be entered by civilian tourists. The private property directly to the east of the buoy
column4: and the beach areas of Truman Annex and Fort Zachary Taylor Historic State Park
column5: also lie farther south than the buoy. The southernmost point of the contiguous United States is Ballast Key
column6: a privately owned island just south and west of Key West. The southernmost location that the public can visit is the beach at Fort Zachary Taylor park.

column1: The monument states "90 Miles to Cuba"
column2: though Key West and Cuba are about 95 statute miles (153 kilometers; 83 nautical miles)
column3: apart at their closest points. The distance from the monument to Havana is about 90 nautical miles (104 statute miles; 167 kilometers).Key West Library

column2: a hurricane destroyed the library. Key West residents moved the library to various locations across the island. The county took over and finally found a permanent location. The library's new location was found in 1959. It was built on Fleming Street

column1: The Key West Library has an ever expanding collection of 70

column1: Several U.S. presidents have visited Key West with the first being Ulysses S. Grant in 1880
column2: followed by Grover Cleveland in 1889
column3: and William Howard Taft in 1912. Taft was the first president to use the first officer's quarters that would later be known as the Little White House. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited the Florida Keys many times
column4: beginning in 1917.Harry S. Truman visited Key West for a total of 175 days on 11 visits during his presidency and visited five times after he left office. His first visit was in 1946. The Little White House and Truman Annex take their names from his frequent and well-documented visits. The residence is also known as the Winter White House as Truman stayed there mostly in the winter months
column5: and used it for official business such as the Truman Doctrine.Dwight D. Eisenhower stayed at the Little White House following a heart attack in 1955. John F. Kennedy visited Key West in March 1961
column6: and in November 1962
column7: a month after the resolution of the Cuban Missile Crisis. Jimmy Carter visited the Little White House twice with his family after he had left office

column1: Legend has it that Ernest Hemingway wrote part of A Farewell to Arms while living above the showroom of a Key West Ford dealership at 314 Simonton Street while awaiting delivery of a Ford Model A roadster purchased by the uncle of his wife Pauline in 1928.Hardware store owner Charles Thompson introduced him to deep-sea fishing.  Among the group who went fishing was Joe Russell (also known as Sloppy Joe).  Russell was reportedly the model for Freddy in To Have and Have Not. Portions of the original manuscript were found at Sloppy Joe's Bar after his death. The group had nicknames for each other
column2: and Hemingway wound up with "Papa".

column1: Pauline's rich uncle Gus Pfeiffer bought the 907 Whitehead Street house in 1931 as a wedding present. The Hemingways installed a swimming pool for $20
column2: 000 in 1937–38 (equivalent to about $291 thousand in 2019). The unexpectedly high cost prompted Hemingway to put a penny in the wet cement of the patio
column3: saying
column4: "Here
column5: take the last penny I've got!" The penny is at the north end of the pool.During his stay he wrote or worked on Death in the Afternoon
column6: For Whom the Bell Tolls
column7: The Snows of Kilimanjaro
column8: and The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber. He used Depression-era Key West as one of the locations in To Have and Have Not—his only novel with scenes that occur in the United States.

column1: The six- or seven-toed polydactyl cats descended from Hemingway's original pet "Snowball" still live on the grounds and are cared for at the Hemingway House
column2: despite complaints by the U.S. Department of Agriculture that they are not kept free from visitor contact. The Key West City Commission has exempted the house from a law prohibiting more than four domestic animals per household.

column1: Pauline and Hemingway divorced in 1939; Hemingway only occasionally visited when returning from Havana until his suicide in 1961.

Tennessee Williams first became a regular visitor to Key West in 1941 and is said to have written the first draft of A Streetcar Named Desire while staying in 1947 at the La Concha Hotel. He bought a permanent house in 1949 and listed Key West as his primary residence until his death in 1983. In contrast to Hemingway's grand house in Old Town
column2: the Williams home at 1431 Duncan Street in the "unfashionable" New Town neighborhood is a very modest bungalow. The house is privately owned and not open to the public. The Academy Award-winning film version of his play The Rose Tattoo was shot on the island in 1956. The Tennessee Williams Theatre is located on the campus of Florida Keys Community College on Stock Island.Even though Hemingway and Williams lived in Key West at the same time
column3: they reportedly met only once—at Hemingway's home in Cuba
column4: Finca Vigía.

the city opened a pier right on Mallory Square.  The decision was met with considerable opposition from people who felt it would disrupt the tradition of watching the sunset at Mallory Square.  Cruise ships now dock at all three piers.
887In present times
column3: several cruise ships dock on a regular basis at Key West
column4: including the Royal Caribbean ship Majesty of the Seas and the Carnival Fascination

column6: however
column7: larger cruise ships have increasingly bypassed Key West due to the narrowness of the island's main ship channel. On October 1
column9: 74% of resident voters opposed a referendum that would have allowed the City Commission to request a feasibility study from the Army Corps of Engineers for a $36 million project to dredge a wider channel. Economic benefits from visiting cruise ship passengers are substantial but not attractive to all Key West citizens as the daily presence of thousands of tourists from cruise ships affects the character of the city
column10: resulting in operation of facilities that cater to mass tourism rather than to an upscale clientele. There are also environmental issues as Key West is surrounded by coral habitat. Concerns over environmental protection were considered a prominent factor in the failure of the 2013 referendum.As of 2009

column1: Key West has a tropical savanna climate (Köppen Aw
column2: similar to the Caribbean islands). Like most tropical climates
column3: Key West has only a small difference in monthly mean temperatures between the coolest month (January) and the warmest month (July) – with the annual range of monthly mean temperatures around 15 °F (8.3 °C). According to the National Weather Service
column4: the Florida Keys and Miami Beach are the only places within the contiguous United States to have never recorded a frost or freeze. The lowest recorded temperature in Key West is 41 °F (5 °C) on January 12
column6: and January 13
column7: 1981. Key West is located in USDA zone 11b (the warmest zone in the contiguous United States). According to the National Weather Service in Key West
column8: low temperatures below 50 F (10 C) occur on average four times per decade.Prevailing easterly tradewinds and sea breezes suppress the usual summertime heating
column9: with temperatures rarely reaching 95 °F (35 °C). There are 55 days per year with 90 °F (32 °C) or greater highs
column10: with the average window for such readings June 10 through September 22
column11: shorter than almost the entire southeastern U.S. Low temperatures often remain above 80 °F (27 °C)
column12: however. The all-time record high temperature is 97 °F (36 °C) on July 19

column2: Key West has a two-season wet and dry climate. The period from November through April is normally sunny and quite dry
column3: with only 25 percent of the annual rainfall occurring. May through October is normally the wet season. During the wet season some rain falls on most days
column4: often as brief
column5: but heavy tropical downpours
column6: followed by intense sun. Early morning is the favored time for these showers
column7: which is different from mainland Florida
column8: where showers and thunderstorms usually occur in the afternoon. Easterly (tropical) waves during this season occasionally bring excessive rainfall
column9: while infrequent hurricanes may be accompanied by unusually heavy amounts. On average
column10: rainfall markedly peaks between August and October; the single wettest month in Key West is September
column11: when the threat from tropical weather systems (hurricanes
column12: tropical storms and tropical depressions) is greatest. Key West is the driest city in Florida
column13: averaging just under 40 inches of rain per year. This is driven primarily by Key West's relative dryness in May
column14: June and July. In mainland Florida peninsular areas like Orlando
column16: June and July average monthly rainfalls typically reach 7 to 10 inches
column17: while Key West has only half such amounts over the same period.

column2: like the rest of the Florida Keys
column3: is vulnerable to hurricanes. In recent history
column4: the island has been relatively unaffected by major storms.  The most recent hurricane to impact Key West was Hurricane Irma
column5: which made landfall in the Keys in the morning of September 10
column6: 2017 as a Category 4 storm.

column1: Some locals maintain that Hurricane Wilma on October 24
column3: was the worst storm in memory.  The entire island was told to evacuate and business owners were forced to shut their doors. After the hurricane had passed
column4: the resulting storm surge sent eight feet (two meters) of water inland completely inundating a large portion of the lower Keys.  Low-lying areas of Key West and the lower Keys
column5: including major tourist destinations
column6: were under as much as three feet (one meter) of water. Sixty percent of the homes in Key West were flooded.  The higher parts of Old Town
column7: such as the Solares Hill and cemetery areas
column8: did not flood
column9: because of their higher elevations of 12 to 18 feet (4 to 5 m).  The surge destroyed tens of thousands of cars throughout the lower Keys
column10: and many houses were flooded with one to two feet (thirty to sixty-one centimeters) of sea water. A local newspaper referred to Key West and the lower Keys as a "car graveyard".  The peak of the storm surge occurred when the eye of Wilma had already passed over the Naples area
column11: and the sustained winds during the surge were less than 40 mph (64 km/h).  The storm destroyed the piers at the clothing-optional Atlantic Shores Motel and breached the shark tank at the Key West Aquarium
column12: freeing its sharks.  Damage postponed the island's famous Halloween Fantasy Fest until the following December. MTV's The Real World: Key West was filming during the hurricane and deals with the storm.

column2: NOAA opened its National Weather Forecasting building on White Street.  The building is designed to withstand a Category 5 hurricane and its storm surge.

column1: The most intense previous hurricane was Hurricane Georges
column2: a Category 2
column3: in September 1998.  The storm damaged many of the houseboats along "Houseboat Row" on South Roosevelt Boulevard near Cow Key channel on the east side of the island.

column1: Many of the residents of Key West were immigrants from the Bahamas
column2: known as Conchs (pronounced "conks"')
column3: who arrived in increasing numbers after 1830. Many were sons and daughters of Loyalists who fled to the nearest Crown soil during the American Revolution.  In the 20th century many residents of Key West started referring to themselves as Conchs
column4: and the term is now generally applied to all residents of Key West.  Some residents use the term "Conch" (or
column5: alternatively
column6: "Saltwater Conch") to refer to a person born in Key West
column7: while the term "Freshwater Conch" refers to a resident not born in Key West but who has lived in Key West for seven years or more. The true original meaning of Conch applies only to someone with European ancestry who immigrated from the Bahamas
column8: however. It is said that when a baby was born
column9: the family would put a conch shell on a pole in front of their home.

column1: Many of the black Bahamian immigrants who arrived later lived in Bahama Village
column2: an area of Old Town next to the Truman Annex.

column1: Key West is closer to Havana (106 miles or 171 kilometres) than it is to Miami (130 mi
column3: Key West had a population of nearly 18
column4: 800 and was the biggest and richest city in Florida. Half the residents were said to be of Cuban origin
column5: and Key West regularly had Cuban mayors
column6: including the son of Carlos Manuel de Céspedes
column7: father of the Cuban Republic
column8: who was elected mayor in 1876. Cubans were actively involved in reportedly 200 factories in town
column9: producing 100 million cigars annually. José Martí made several visits to seek recruits for Cuban independence starting in 1891 and founded the Cuban Revolutionary Party during his visits to Key West.Key West was flooded with refugees during the Mariel Boatlift. Refugees continue to come ashore and
column12: flew hijacked Cuban Airlines planes into the city's airport.

column1: Key West Government is governed via the mayor-council system. The city council is known as the city commission. It consists of six members each elected from individual districts. The mayor is elected in a citywide vote.

Mayors of Key West have reflected the city's cultural and ethnic heritage.  Among its mayors are the first Cuban mayor and one of the first openly gay mayors. One mayor is also famous for having water-skied to Cuba.

column2: Boca Chica and the Truman Annex have been the home of U.S. ships
column3: submarines
column4: Pegasus-class hydrofoils and Fighter Training Squadrons like the VF101 detachment. NAS Key West is still a training facility for top gun pilots.Key West has had a military presence since 1823
column5: shortly after its purchase by Simonton in 1822. John W. Simonton lobbied the U.S. government to establish a naval base on Key West
column6: both to take advantage of its strategic location and to bring law and order to the Key West town. On March 25
column8: naval officer Matthew C. Perry sailed the schooner Shark to Key West and planted the U.S. flag claiming the Keys as United States property. In 1823 A naval base was established to protect shipping merchants in the lower keys from pirates. The original base is now known as Mallory Square.

column1: Key West was always an important military post
column2: since it sits at the northern edge of the deepwater channel connecting the Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico (the southern edge 90 miles [140 km] away is Cuba) via the Florida Straits. Because of this
column3: Key West since the 1820s had been dubbed the "Gibraltar of the West".  Fort Taylor was initially built on the island. The Navy added a small base from which the USS Maine sailed to its demise in Havana at the beginning of the Spanish–American War.

column1: At the beginning of World War II the Navy increased its presence from 50 to 3
column2: 000 acres (20 to 1
column3: 214 hectares)
column4: including  all of Boca Chica Key's 1
column5: 700 acres (690 ha) and the construction of Fleming Key from landfill. The Navy built the first water pipeline extending the length of the Keys
column6: bringing fresh water from the mainland to supply its bases. At its peak 15
column7: 000 military personnel and 3
column8: 400 civilians were at the base. Included in the base are:

column1: Naval Air Station Key West – This is the main facility on Boca Chica
column2: where the Navy trains its pilots. Staff are housed at Sigsbee Park. In 2006 there were 1
column3: 650 active-duty personnel; 2
column4: 507 family members; 35 Reserve members; and 1
column5: 312 civilians listed at the base. In the 1990s the Navy worked out an agreement with the National Park Service to stop sonic booms near Fort Jefferson in the Dry Tortugas.  Many of the training missions are directed at the Marquesas "Patricia" Target 29 nautical miles (54 km) due west of the base. The target is a grounded ship hulk 306 feet (93 m) in length that is visible only at low tide. Bombs are not actually dropped on the target.

column1: Truman Annex – The area next to Fort Taylor became a submarine pen and was used for the Fleet Sonar School. President Harry S. Truman was to make the commandant's house his winter White House.  The Fort Taylor Annex was later renamed the Truman Annex. This portion has largely been decommissioned and turned over to private developers and the city of Key West. There are still a few government offices there
column2: however
column3: including the new NOAA Hurricane Forecasting Center. The Navy still owns its piers.

column1: Trumbo Annex – The docking area on what had been the railroad yard for Flagler's Overseas Railroad is now used by the Coast Guard.

Key West is part of the Miami-Fort Lauderdale television market. It is served by rebroadcast transmitters in Key West and Marathon that repeat the Miami-Fort Lauderdale stations. Comcast provides cable television service. DirecTV and Dish Network provide Miami-Fort Lauderdale local stations and national channels.
The Key West area has 11 FM radio stations
column2: 4 FM translators
column3: and 2 AM stations. WEOW 92.7 is the home of The Rude Girl & Molly Blue
column4: a popular morning zoo duo; Bill Bravo is the afternoon host. SUN 99.5 has Hoebee and Miss Loretta in the p.m. drive.  Island 107.1 FM is the only locally owned
column5: independent FM station in Key West
column6: featuring alternative rock music and community programs.

column1: The Florida Keys Keynoter and the Key West Citizen are published locally and serve Key West and Monroe County. The Southernmost Flyer
column2: a weekly publication printed in conjunction with the Citizen
column3: is produced by the Public Affairs Department of Naval Air Station Key West and serves the local military community. Key West the Newspaper (known locally as The Blue Paper due to its colorful header) is a local weekly investigative newspaper
column4: established in 1994 by Dennis Cooper
column5: taken over in 2013 as a fully digital publication by Arnaud and Naja Girard.

column1: Monroe County School District operates public schools in Key West.
District-operated elementary schools serving the City of Key West include Poinciana Elementary School
column2: which is located on the island of Key West
column3: and Gerald Adams Elementary School
column4: which is located on Stock Island. District-operated middle and high schools include Horace O'Bryant School
column5: a former middle school that now operates as a K–8 school
column6: and the Key West High School. All of Key West is zoned to Horace O'Bryant School for grades 6-8 and to Key West High School for grades 9–12. Sigsbee Charter School is a K–8 school
column7: sanctioned by the District and serving predominantly military dependent children as well as children from the community at large. Admission to Sigsbee Charter School is limited and the waiting list is managed by a lottery system. Key West Montessori Charter School is a district-sanctioned charter school on Key West Island.The main campus of Florida Keys Community College is located in Key West.
